summary: Ted Winicov is mentioned in four journal entries from the Office of Legislative Counsel, all dated November 10, 1977. The entries detail the office's daily activities, which include responding to employment requests, liaising with congressional offices and committees, and managing security matters. Specifically, the journals mention liaison activities with the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) and the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. The journals also note managing access for Senate Select Committee on Intelligence staff to sensitive materials. While the documents mention Ted Winicov, they do not specify his role or connection to the JFK assassination. The documents suggest that the Office of Legislative Counsel was involved in facilitating access to information and coordinating with congressional committees investigating the assassination.
significance: The documents suggest that Ted Winicov was likely a staff member within the Office of Legislative Counsel during the time when the House Select Committee on Assassinations was actively investigating the JFK assassination. However, the exact role and significance of Ted Winicov in the JFK assassination context cannot be determined from the provided documents.
